meanings.def: to support the weight of somebody/something and take them or it from place to place; to take somebody/something from one place to another
examples: carry somebody/something He was carrying a large bag.
to carry a sign/banner/flag
The plane was carrying 122 passengers and five crew.
carry somebody/something + adv./prep. She carried her baby in her arms.
The injured were carried away on stretchers.
a train carrying commuters to work
A train carrying hundreds of commuters was derailed this morning.
He carried her on his back for over five miles.
He was carrying a battered suitcase.
How are we going to get this home? It's too heavy to carry.
Several of the ships carrying troops to the area were torpedoed.
Some of the protesters were carrying placards.
The boat can carry up to five people.
The little girl was exhausted and wanted to be carried.
The truck was carrying illegal drugs worth up to $2 million.
Women here have to carry water two miles from the nearest well.

meanings.def: to have something with you and take it wherever you go
examples: carry something to carry a weapon/knife
Police in many countries carry guns.
carry something + adv./prep. I never carry much money on me.
I always carry my diary with me.
I don't like carrying a lot of money around.
He carries around an ancient old blanket.

meanings.def: to contain and direct the flow of water, electricity, etc.
examples: carry something a pipeline carrying oil
carry something + adv./prep. The veins carry blood to the heart.
Canals were built to carry water from the Snake River to Milner Dam in 1905.
Blood vessels carry blood to every part of the body.
The heated air is carried by flues to the walls.
The pipelines carry oil across Siberia.

meanings.def: if a person, an insect, etc. carries a disease, they have already caught it and might spread it to others although they might not become ill themselves
examples: Ticks can carry a nasty disease which affects humans.

meanings.def: to be able to remember something
to support the weight of something
examples: A road bridge has to carry a lot of traffic.
The roof is designed to carry huge loads of snow.

meanings.def: to accept responsibility for something; to suffer the results of something
examples: He is carrying the department (= it is only working because of his efforts).
Their group was targeted to carry the burden of job losses.
She carries a full load of classes while also serving as department head.

meanings.def: to have something as a quality or feature
examples: Her speech carried the ring of authority.
Each bike carries a ten-year guarantee.

meanings.def: to have something as a result
examples: Crimes of violence carry heavy penalties.
The charge carries a maximum sentence of ten years.
Being a combat sport, karate carries with it the risk of injury.

meanings.def: if something that is thrown, kicked, etc. carries a particular distance, it travels that distance before stopping
examples: The fullback's kick carried 50 metres into the crowd.

meanings.def: if a sound carries, it can be heard a long distance away
to take something/somebody to a particular point or in a particular direction
examples: The war was carried into enemy territory.
Her abilities carried her to the top of her profession.

meanings.def: to approve of something by more people voting for it than against it
examples: The resolution was carried by 340 votes to 210.

meanings.def: to win the support or sympathy of somebody; to persuade people to accept your argument
examples: carry somebody His moving speech was enough to carry the audience.
carry something She nodded in agreement, and he saw he had carried his point.

meanings.def: to have a particular label attached; to give a particular message or piece of information
examples: Cigarettes carry a health warning.
All the marketing carries a consistent message of quality and reliability.

meanings.def: if a newspaper, broadcast, etc. carries a particular story, it publishes or broadcasts it
if a shop carries a particular item, it has it for sale
examples: We carry a range of educational software.
We do carry green tea, but we don't have any (in stock) right now.

meanings.def: to be pregnant with somebody
examples: She was carrying twins.

meanings.def: to hold or move your head or body in a particular way
examples: to carry yourself well

meanings.def: to add a number to the next column on the left when adding up numbers, for example when the numbers add up to more than ten
as quickly as you can
to get very excited or lose control of your feelings
examples: I got carried away and started shouting at the television.

meanings.def: to be completely successful
to take responsibility for getting something done
examples: My co-worker was sick, so I had to carry the ball.

meanings.def: to accept the blame for something, especially when it is not your fault
to be successful against somebody/something
examples: Despite strong opposition, the ruling party carried the day.
Teamwork and persistence can still win the day.

meanings.def: to continue doing something beyond reasonable limits
to be in love with somebody, especially somebody who does not love you in return
to have influence with somebody
examples: My views don't carry much weight with the boss.

meanings.def: to do a lot of little jobs for somebody as if you were their servant
examples: Most of her day was spent fetching and carrying for her family.
She expected him to do all the fetching and carrying.

idioms.idiom: as fast as your legs can carry you

idioms.def: to get very excited or lose control of your feelings
examples: I got carried away and started shouting at the television.

idioms.def: to take responsibility for getting something done
examples: My co-worker was sick, so I had to carry the ball.

idioms.def: to accept the blame for something, especially when it is not your fault

examples: Despite strong opposition, the ruling party carried the day.
Teamwork and persistence can still win the day.

idioms.def: to continue doing something beyond reasonable limits
to be in love with somebody, especially somebody who does not love you in return

examples: My views don't carry much weight with the boss.

idioms.def: to do a lot of little jobs for somebody as if you were their servant
examples: Most of her day was spent fetching and carrying for her family.
She expected him to do all the fetching and carrying.

meanings.def: the act of carrying something from one place to another
examples: We did a carry of equipment from the camp.

meanings.def: the practice of carrying a gun in public
examples: Each state makes its own laws concerning the carry of weapons.
